alert.note: Alert for Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Susitna Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued December 19 at 6:09AM AKST by NWS Anchorage
info.description: ...WINTER STORM TO IMPACT WESTERN KENAI PENINSULA, ANCHORAGE, AND THE MAT-SU VALLEYS MONDAY... Snow is expected to develop Monday morning from the Western Kenai Peninsula north to the Mat-Su Valleys. The snow is expected to start off as west snow before transitioning to a drier, more powdery snow by Monday afternoon or evening. Snowfall rates are also expected to increase late Monday, especially for east Anchorage and along the Glenn Highway from Palmer to Anchorage as a colder northwesterly flow develops. Snowfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches is possible for the Western Kenai Peninsula; 2 to 4 inches are possible for the Susitna Valley, mainly along the Parks Highway from Talkeetna south; and 4 to 8 inches are possible for the Anchorage Bowl and Matanuska Valley. The highest snowfall totals are expected from Palmer south along the Glenn Highway to east Anchorage and the Anchorage Hillside. This weather system will also usher in warmer air aloft over Cook Inlet Monday morning with the potential for the onset of precipitation to be in the form of a wintry mix of snow/sleet/freezing rain for portions of the Western Kenai Peninsula. Any wintry mix is expected to quickly change to all snow by mid morning Monday. Farther south, warmer air near the surface will move over the Southern Cook Inlet and into Kachemak Bay, allowing a transition to rain for Homer. Snow may linger along upslope locations of the Chugach and Kenai Mountains through early Tuesday morning before tapering off as this system moves east. There is still some uncertainty with the exact details of this system, so we will be closely monitoring this system as it develops. This system may impact travel across the area to start the week. For the latest informations go to www.weather.gov/anchorage.

area.areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Susitna Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula
